channel.title: Comments on: Book: On Basilisk Station

item.title: By: Martin
item.dc:creator: Martin
item.description:
From (distant) memory, it is pretty rough stuff at first. It gets much better - occassionally great - peaks around book five or six, then descends rapidly into self-indulgent multi-narrative political stuff that could really do with a read of House of Cards to see how to say something without actually taking 200 pages to do so. They also dwell more and more on the (US) right-wing prejudices of the writer and his readership. Not unattractive, just a little smug, and again fascinated with the idea that monarchies might be better systems than outright democracies. What is it about conservative Americans and the Cult of the Great Leader? I just don't get it.
Honor does develop as a character, but if you don't like the 'ugly duckling doesn't yet realise she's a swan' thing, it may prove more of a slog than you are willing to bear, as her lack of personal confidence does remain a key element in the early series.
The books themselves are less Aubrey/Maturin than Nelson re-written, so there's no double-act. At their best they are rip-roaring reads, and the space battles are extremely well-done. I'd have given it a 3, but only because I had read a later one first. Info-dumps of all sorts do remain an issue; your mileage may vary on this one. Some I read, being a bit of a details freak for the techie stuff, som of it I skim, some I flip past.
Gap is a very different kettle of fish, I think - like a comparison of LOTR to Sword of Shanarra. Weber is primarily a popcorn writer. Tasty though!
